title: Online Knowledge Resource for European Buildings

author: Dan Staniaszek, Buildings Performance Institute Europe (BPIE)

segmentation: Good afternoon with all this talk of big data and why the only one who keeps a good Big Brother.
I'm just wondering, maybe it's not appropriate comment for this type of audience, but maybe it's an issue that is something if we want to talk about big data to consumers.
But anyway to my to my presentation I'm going to talk about buildings and edge performance.

I mean if you look out your window you'll see hotel you see some buildings or whatever there about 200 million buildings across Europe and our aim was to try and categorize that for the purposes of knowing what their energy consumption is, the energy performance and how much energy and carbon emissions we can save.
Because most people don't appreciate it, but buildings account for the largest proportion of CO2 emissions not only in Europe but in many other parts of the world.

So, but it's very dispersed, so we heard the talk earlier in the morning about the the supply side and the power stations and the smart grids and the like, and also some of the interactions about the solar panels on on rooves and how they interact with the supply side.
But at the end of the day, it's buildings and it's little things like houses and.
Office blocks that actually are consuming energy individually in small quantities, but collectively very significant, and so the idea here was very much of.

While pulling that data together, creating an online platform that categorizes the building stock across Europe in a way that's never been done before, so this is the the biggest collection we believe of.
Data on energy, performance of buildings and it's collected from 29 countries at the moment we are going to expand that.

And we had to collect it in a very old fashioned way, basically doing a survey, getting people to fill in experts in each country, filling the information to give us the the knowledge, and then virtually manually enter that into a specific data platform data hub that's been developed for that purpose.
But the idea was very much about creating the ability to do comparisons between countries across countries, collect information, not only statistical information on buildings, but also.
What the legislative position is?
How well are different countries implementing the myriad of European legislation and the ability to present that and for people to download that information for free?
Just just to clarify, we're building performance Institute are a nonprofit organization, so our information is available for free.
And as I say, you'll see there.
Website at the end.
So the objective is for the the data hub to be the first point of contact for anyone interested in energy performance of buildings.
Provide a multi source and up-to-date facts and figures sheet.

I qualify that we're not getting data in real time yet, but I hope at some point down the future in the future we will maybe with your help you can advise us how we can get there so we're still relying on a survey undertaken on 2011 two years ago that was probably based on data that was variously 345 years old, so it's not being up to date, but we want it to be.
It allows users anywhere in the world to access that data and search it and make comparisons and visualization, and to download the information, enable us.
Monitor progress against the these various policies, which I won't bore you with, but there are lots of them.
And really just look to improve.
We just launched the system just four or five months ago, so it's very early days yet, but we've already got a whole load of ideas about how to make it better.
We're getting feedback from a server just undertook, so just really understanding how else we can augment our own data with datasets from other parties so.
There it is.
There's a little kind of logo in terms of the competitive open data portal.
Reiterating many of the things I've said, so we're really hoping that this is a very good qualitie, very comprehensive data.
Net.

And the little publication there in the bottom is really the one of the main reports we published on the basis of all the data we collected and for policy wonks, if I can call them that in the energy field.
You know, a lot of people say this is great, that we've actually managed to pull this information together for the first time to allow these comparisons.
So we're going to be building on that knowledge platform and.
We we do access information from Euro stat from EA from other sources and we are looking to.
I mean some of these logos.
You'll recognize some you probably most probably won't, but we are looking at actively at linking with others who are operating in the same field who've got data that we're interested in.
But really, it's I think we're still at a very early stage in terms of true open data and be able to be able to match up data from different sources.
And really.
Make it very streamlined because at the moment it is quite hard going and quite labor intensive to to actually get new data and to bring it in.
And again, we just reiterate.
We're here to really provide that public good in terms of helping policy makers make the right policy decisions in terms of knowing what the evidence bases in terms of energy consumption.
What you can do to build different buildings depending on their age, their energy use, their current state of energy performance, etc etc.
So.
A whole load of data on the building stock when it was built is in the public sector.
What kind of climates is it located in, what insulation levels etc.
And also legislation at a country level, so each country has got its own kind of rules and regulations.
But also there's some pan European stuff that everyone has to implement as it won't be a surprise to anyone.
But it's not implemented uniformly.
Again, which won't be surprised to everyone.
So how are different countries?
Interpreting that data and how are they implementing it?
So just a little snapshot about the data we've collected and this comparing kind of 16 building related technologies like what's the installation of the walls, the floor, etc.

And actually, there's there's only one or two countries that actually gave us the full data set of 16 items, and you can see it rapidly kind of pans off, and overall we probably only got about 3/4 of the available data, not because it doesn't exist.
It does, but a we're talking about 2425 different languages.
Maybe it's maybe half a dozen different information sources in those countries and see how we ask the right people for that information.
In future, we want to link automatically with the data sources, the National Statistics, the census results, etc that are going to give us that data directly, but were some way off that just yet.
This is just one of the outputs, so I don't have time for a demo, but this is just one.
The outputs are showing the floor area by country across European countries.
It's it's all very important use.
Perhaps no surprise here.
The bigger countries have got more floor area, but I think its ability to drill down and extract that data and do the analysis that is of.

And again, you won't be able to read this, but this is more the descriptive material about different financial schemes grants grand scheme, support schemes, soft loans, etc that are there to encourage in different countries.
People to insulate their buildings or install better, more efficient heating systems and their various options are in terms of downloads and radio buttons that you.
Press and this is 1 example of a country fact sheet from Austria and you can download about 20 page PDF.
So system architecture.
Clearly we we structure the data in terms the building we actually haven't done that bit yet, but we certainly charts.
And then there's the outputs in terms of searching so pretty familiar stuff.
So flick through that you know there's the architecture, which again, you can't read that.
I'm sure you wouldn't be interested anyway, but yes, there is an architecture behind.
So I mentioned the quite laborious process of collecting the data first time round.
It was conducted offline through a process of engaging with external experts.
There's a lot of manual checking and there was lots of interpretation.
You know in the UK and Ireland we have a comma for thousands, but on the continent lots of people have.
You know?
So better identify things like are we out by a factor of 1000?
Or maybe someone meant to do a factory 1000, but they didn't say it was.
So all these kind of reality checks and.

Viability checks we needed to do and then actually to pull it into some sort of coherent format where you could actually make that data available online in a way that is usable and interpretable so it was a very long and expensive and at times quite pain.

Process we are looking to improve that with a still to be determined, but principally in online type survey where in an ideal world we'd be able to engage directly with the experts in each country that have got the data that can upload it or provide a kind of some kind of automatic linkage and with a very simple kind of sense check we can then make it upload, upload it with with a matter of days and it's kind of virtually alive system.
And I say there's a whole lot of other stuff in there, but that's the that's the idea.
I guess I'll skip over that, but this just goes so goes to show that we are looking to expand the scope of what we're doing as well.
So more and more information on more and more aspects of the building performance.
We started off with the stuff that we think is the vitals, the vital statistics.
If you like the number of buildings, the floor area, the energy use and we're kind of growing that progressively.
And here are some of the results.
We launched this the system in November last year and surprise surprise with all the publicity around that, there is a peak very shortly after that.
Quite a lot of interest for the first few weeks that we had Christmas and New Year, and then since that we're having that kind of the weekly patterns they should expect.
So we're getting kind of.
8090 hundred people a day, which isn't bad for quite a technical thing.
We've had whatever it is.
Nearly 4000 unique visitors, which we're pretty pleased with and a lot of people coming back.
So there is a kind of a regular usage, and for the most part, we're not kind of publicizing it in any particular way.
But you know, here, for example, there was a newsletter, and here there was something else, so there are occasional spikes.
So yeah, we're obviously monitoring it, and so far pretty pleased with what we've got there.
And we are getting usage from across the world.
Surprise, surprise, most of it is in Europe because it is a European data hub.
But we've got everyone from, you know, Japan to Australia to Zim, Zimbabwe, Zambia, certainly in South Africa and places in between.
So it's there and it's getting there and.
We did deliver a part of a kind of a global network, and so we deliberately developed this European hub for it to be replicable in the States in China and India in other places.
That is yet to happen.
But the the potential is certainly there, so we were pretty pleased with what we've got so far.
I mean, I think we're very keen to make the whole process a lot easier and cheaper in terms of getting the data, make it available to people, and actually linking with other parties.
So if you got any brilliant ideas about how to do that.
Then do please let me know.
Thank you very much.
